headline.main-hed: Judge Orders Philadelphia Man Detained for Alleged Role in Nazi Death Camp

alt-summary-body.p: A judge ordered federal authorities Wednesday to detain an 89-year-old Philadelphia man before deciding whether he will be sent to Germany to face charges connected to his alleged role as a Nazi death camp guard.

headline.main-hed: Judge orders Philadelphia man detained on charges related to Nazi death camp
Man Ordered Detained for Alleged Role in Nazi Death Camp -- Update
Man Ordered Detained for Alleged Role in Nazi Death Camp

summary-body.p: A judge ordered federal authorities Wednesday to detain an 89-year-old Philadelphia man before deciding whether he will be sent to Germany to face charges connected to his alleged role as a Nazi death camp guard.

headline.main-hed: Judge Orders Philadelphia Man Detained on Charges Related to Nazi Death Camp
headline.deck: German Authorities Allege Breyer Had Role in Hundreds of Thousands of Deaths at Poland's Birkenau

article-body.p: A judge ordered federal authorities to keep an 89-year-old Philadelphia man in custody before deciding whether he will be sent to Germany to face charges tied to his alleged role as a Nazi death camp guard.

It is the latest twist in a long-running effort by German authorities to prosecute Johann Breyer, a retired tool maker who emigrated to the U.S. in 1952, for his alleged role at Auschwitz II-Birkenau, part of the Auschwitz complex in German-occupied Poland during World War II.

U.S. Marshals arrested Mr. Breyer on Tuesday at his home. On Wednesday, Judge Timothy Rice of the U.S. District Court in Philadelphia ordered Mr. Breyer to remain in custody until an extradition hearing is held Aug. 21.
Mr. Breyer has acknowledged serving as a guard at Auschwitz but has denied that he played any role in the killing of prisoners at Birkenau.

An earlier effort by the Justice Department to strip Mr. Breyer of his citizenship and deport him ended in 2003 when a federal appeals court affirmed a previous judge's ruling that his Nazi service was involuntary.

"There have already been a number of hearings where the allegations made by the German government have been proven false," Dennis Boyle, Mr. Breyer's attorney, said in an interview before Wednesday's hearing. "I don't think this is something that has any merit or should move forward."

German authorities issued a warrant for Mr. Breyer's arrest in June 2013 and have charged him with aiding and abetting the murders of 158 trainloads of European Jews, or about 216,000 people. Prosecutors in Weiden, Germany, have asked U.S. authorities to extradite him so he can stand trial in Germany.

A criminal complaint unsealed Wednesday said Mr. Breyer served as a guard in the Waffen-SS at Auschwitz II-Birkenau from 1943 to January 1945. German prosecutors have charged him with complicity in the murder of 158 trainloads of European Jewish deportees.
Approximately 216,000 people transported by those trains were murdered in gas chambers and cremated when they arrived at Auschwitz II-Birkenau between May 1944 and October 1944, the complaint says.

The complaint alleges that Mr. Breyer served in the Death's Head Guard Battalion. Gas chambers and crematoria were visible from the living quarters of the guards, and when deportees got off the train they were surrounded by Death's Head guards, the complaint says. Guards then marched two-thirds of those who arrived directly to gas chambers, the complaint further states.

After enlisting at age 17, Mr. Breyer first served as an armed guard at the Buchenwald concentration camp for several months in 1943 before being transferred to Auschwitz II-Birkenau, the complaint alleges.

His transfer record is no longer available, but prosecutors have relied on a number of other war-time records, Mr. Breyer's past statements and that his guard company was consistently assigned to Auschwitz II-Birkenau. They wrote that there is the "highest degree of probability" that he was part of the transfer group.

While stationed at Auschwitz II-Birkenau, Mr. Breyer was promoted at least once and was granted leave twice, the complaint alleges. "Such benefits were not afforded to a guard who failed or refused to perform the full range of duties of an SS Death's Head Battalion guard," prosecutors wrote.

About 1.1 million Jews and 200,000 other prisoners were deported to Auschwitz between 1941 and 1944 from German-occupied Europe. At least 960,000 Jews and more than 100,000 other victims were killed there. At height of deportations, up to 6,000 Jews were killed at Auschwitz a day, according to the U.S. Holocaust Memorial Museum.
Write to Kris Maher at kris.maher@wsj.com
